title: Hypoglycemia Risk Score
description: Predicts 12-month risk of hypoglycemic episodes in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) patients for population management and targeted interventions

parameters.name: hypoglycemia_admissions
parameters.description: Number of previous hypoglycemia-related hospital admissions

parameters.name: ed_visits_12_months
parameters.description: Number of emergency department visits in the last 12 months

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of hypoglycemia-related hospitalization. No previous admissions, no high-risk medications (insulin/sulfonylurea), age <77 years, and no severe kidney disease.
Moderate risk of hypoglycemia-related hospitalization. Consider clinical review and targeted interventions based on individual risk factors.
High risk of hypoglycemia-related hospitalization. Priority for targeted interventions including medication review, continuous glucose monitoring, and specialized care coordination.

references: Karter AJ, Warton EM, Lipska KJ, et al. Development and Validation of a Tool to Identify Patients With Type 2 Diabetes at High Risk of Hypoglycemia-Related Emergency Department or Hospital Use. JAMA Intern Med. 2017;177(10):1461-1470. doi:10.1001/jamainternmed.2017.3844
Lipska KJ, Warton EM, Huang ES, et al. HbA1c and risk of severe hypoglycemia in type 2 diabetes: the Diabetes and Aging Study. Diabetes Care. 2013;36(11):3535-42. doi: 10.2337/dc13-0610
formula: Risk stratification based on clinical risk factors: previous hypoglycemia admissions (highest weight), insulin/sulfonylurea use, severe kidney disease (eGFR ≤29), age ≥77 years, and frequent ED visits
notes: Designed for population management rather than individual patient risk assessment
High-risk patients: ≥3 previous hypoglycemia admissions OR 1-2 previous admissions with insulin use
Low-risk patients: No previous admissions, no insulin/sulfonylurea, age <77, no severe kidney disease
All other combinations classify as intermediate risk
Validated in multiple external cohorts but prospective application studies are needed
Intended to facilitate targeted interventions: medication simplification, CGM, psychosocial support
